title: Unauthorized Access via Join Email Link

activities.message: When is this going to get triaged?
activities.markdown_message: When is this going to get triaged?

activities.message:
Hi,

Thanks for the report. We've filed a ticket internally to reproduce the error and release a patch for it. We will contact you shortly if we require more information or with any updates.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

Thanks for the report. We've filed a ticket internally to reproduce the error and release a patch for it. We will contact you shortly if we require more information or with any updates.

activities.message:
Hi,

This is a quick update to everyone to has submitted an issue - we are a bit overwhelmed with the initial response to the launch of our HackerOne bug bounty program, and are continuing to go through all of your tickets. We appreciate your patience as we investigate and triage all of your submissions.

Best,
WePay Team

activities.message: Checking in to see if there are any updates on this?
activities.markdown_message: Checking in to see if there are any updates on this?

activities.message:
There is not yet an update on this ticket. We need to prioritize our backlog of tasks, and this has not yet bubbled-up to the top of the stack. We will respond once we have pushed this change live.

Thanks for checking-in!

There is not yet an update on this ticket. We need to prioritize our backlog of tasks, and this has not yet bubbled-up to the top of the stack. We will respond once we have pushed this change live.

Thanks for checking-in!

activities.message:
Hi,

This is low priority issue, and thus will take some time to fix. We will update you as soon as a fix is deployed.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hello Naissa, Happy New Year :)

Any updates on this one?
activities.markdown_message:
Hello Naissa, Happy New Year :)

activities.message: All right. This is it! I have waited long enough for an update and my patience is running out. This is to let you know that I will be blogging about this issue unless I hear otherwise by May 1, 2015.

activities.message:
Hi,

We are working on fixing all security issues. this seems low priorty. what is the change someone will send an invite and then delete that invite? pretty low. however, we've added the issue to our backlog for fix. sorry for the wait.

activities.message:
Are you saying that inviting a wrong email address is not likely? The person inviting might not even realize that and when he/she does that, it'll be too late. It might be a low priority for WePay, sure but the exploitability is very much likely. 

And, inspite of repeated requests for about 6 months, there were no updates whatsoever hence the comment above. 

Do you guys have any SLAs for fixing low priority issues? I think 10 months is more than enough time to even fix low priority issues. I will follow up again in 3 months and if by that time, the issue is still not fixed. I will publicly disclose it. Thanks for the reply!
activities.markdown_message:
Are you saying that inviting a wrong email address is not likely? The person inviting might not even realize that and when he/she does that, it'll be too late. It might be a low priority for WePay, sure but the exploitability is very much likely.

And, inspite of repeated requests for about 6 months, there were no updates whatsoever hence the comment above.

Do you guys have any SLAs for fixing low priority issues? I think 10 months is more than enough time to even fix low priority issues. I will follow up again in 3 months and if by that time, the issue is still not fixed. I will publicly disclose it. Thanks for the reply!

activities.message: this is pretty minor because the person who gets access to that account cannot move money or anything ... they can't do anything important on the account.
activities.markdown_message: this is pretty minor because the person who gets access to that account cannot move money or anything ... they can't do anything important on the account.

activities.message:
This has been triaged. We will work to get this into an upcoming sprint. Because of the low-severity of the impact, this has a lower priority.

We have had several high-priority projects happening over the past 6 months (e.g., datacenter migration, substantial scalability ramps), and while this is a valid issue, other issues have been substantially higher-impact and have required most/all of our engineering staff.

We will continue to keep an eye on this, and prioritize it as appropriate according to our staff resources and business priorities. Please continue to be patient.
activities.markdown_message:

We will continue to keep an eye on this, and prioritize it as appropriate according to our staff resources and business priorities. Please continue to be patient.

activities.message: Yes, thanks a lot for the updates. I am patient as long as I am updated within a reasonable amount of time. Cheers!
activities.markdown_message: Yes, thanks a lot for the updates. I am patient as long as I am updated within a reasonable amount of time. Cheers!

activities.message: Your bug has been fixed! Please confirm that you are no longer able to reproduce the issue. We will now make a determination on compensation for this bug. Please be patient throughout this process!
activities.markdown_message: Your bug has been fixed! Please confirm that you are no longer able to reproduce the issue. We will now make a determination on compensation for this bug. Please be patient throughout this process!

vulnerability_information_html:
1. User A adds User B's email address and grants User B as a member of his application. This shows pending under Settings -> Access.

  2. User B receives an email for joining User A's application but does not act upon it yet.

  3. User A changes his mind and deletes User B from his application invitations which was still in the pending state. User A no longer wants User B as a member of his application.

  4. User B now clicks on the link received and signs up. As soon as he is signed up, User B can now access User A's application.

So, inspite of User A having deleted the invitation to User B, User B was still able to sign up and access User A's application.

PS - When User A refreshes the Access page again, he can now see User B as a member of his application. If User A deletes User B again now and if User B uses the same old link again to sign up, User B will no longer have access to User A's application. This is all right and this is how it should be.

But, the steps described above should not have happened. User B should not have been able to use the link in his email to sign up and access User A's application especially when User A had deleted his invitation to User B.
vulnerability_information:
1. User A adds User B's email address and grants User B as a member of his application. This shows pending under Settings -> Access. 

2. User B receives an email for joining User A's application but does not act upon it yet. 

3. User A changes his mind and deletes User B from his application invitations which was still in the pending state. User A no longer wants User B as a member of his application. 

4. User B now clicks on the link received and signs up. As soon as he is signed up, User B can now access User A's application. 

So, inspite of User A having deleted the invitation to User B, User B was still able to sign up and access User A's application. 

PS - When User A refreshes the Access page again, he can now see User B as a member of his application. If User A deletes User B again now and if User B uses the same old link again to sign up, User B will no longer have access to User A's application. This is all right and this is how it should be. 

But, the steps described above should not have happened.  User B should not have been able to use the link in his email to sign up and access User A's application especially when User A had deleted his invitation to User B.
